title: Distribution of sampling weights
text: vignette shows step--step examples distribute hypothetical sampling weights reference spatial grid. First, sampling weights generated based distance shoreline. Spatial grid cells within 10 km, 30 km, 50 km shoreline assigned sampling weights 1, 0.15, 0.01 respectively. Grid cells beyond 50 km assigned sampling weights 0. Next, sampling weights generated based depth. Spatial grid cells median depths 10-20 m, 20-50 m assigned sampling weights 1 0.5, respectively. Finally, two different sampling weights area combined produce single sampling weight spatial grid cell.

text: reference spatial grid used originated Koropatnick & Coffen-Smout (2020). cropped Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization (NAFO) Division 4T, median depth assigned grid cell based General Bathymetric Chart Oceans (GEBCO) 2024.

title: Distribution of sampling weights
text: Spatial grid cells within 10 km, 30 km, 50 km shoreline assigned hypothetical sampling weights 1, 0.15, 0.01 respectively. Grid cells beyond 50 km assigned sampling weights 0.
code: buffers<-c(50,30,10)#km weights<-c(0.01,0.15,1) ref_grid$dist.wght<-0 for(i in 1:length(buffers)){   buf<-buffer(coast_coarse,buffers[i]*1000)   index<-intersect(ref_grid,buf)   ref_grid[which(ref_grid$OBJECTID%in%index$OBJECTID),'dist.wght']<-weights[i]   }  ref_grid #>  class       : SpatVector  #>  geometry    : polygons  #>  dimensions  : 11124, 6  (geometries, attributes) #>  extent      : 1864640, 2608453, 1092588, 1564352  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #>  coord. ref. : Canada_Albers_Equal_Area_Conic (ESRI:102001)  #>  names       :  OBJECTID  GRID_ID depth.med  nafo  area dist.wght #>  type        :     <num>    <chr>     <num> <chr> <num>     <num> #>  values      :  2.57e+05 ATD-1220     9.867    4T  7.84         1 #>                2.581e+05 ATE-1219     4.908    4T 8.762         1 #>                2.581e+05 ATF-1219     10.57    4T 9.833         1  ggplot()+   geom_spatvector(data=ref_grid,aes(fill=dist.wght))+   scale_fill_viridis_c(direction=-1)

title: Distribution of sampling weights
text: Spatial grid cells median depths 10-20 m, 20-50 m assigned hypothetical sampling weights 1 0.5, respectively. grid cells assigned sampling weights 0.
code: start.depths<-c(10,20) stop.depths<-c(20,50) weights<-c(1,0.5) ref_grid$depth.wght<-0 for(i in 1:length(start.depths)){   index<-which(ref_grid$depth.med>=start.depths[i]&ref_grid$depth.med<stop.depths[i])   ref_grid[index,'depth.wght']<-weights[i]     }  ggplot()+   geom_spatvector(data=ref_grid,aes(fill=depth.wght))+   scale_fill_viridis_c(direction=-1)

title: Distribution of sampling weights
text: hypothetical example, distance shore depth sampling weights multiplied produce single sampling weight grid cell.
code: ref_grid$wght<-ref_grid$dist.wght*ref_grid$depth.wght  #for plotting purposes, change values of zero to NA ref_grid[which(ref_grid$wght==0),'wght']<-NA  ggplot()+   geom_spatvector(data=ref_grid,aes(fill=wght))+   scale_fill_viridis_c(direction=-1,na.value = 'white')

title: Spatial Weight Informed Mapping
text: Functions Spatial Weight Informed Mapping (SWIM), enables integration data incongruent sources generate heterogeneous layer sampling weights. Events missing geographic coordinates assigned spatial grid using probability-based framework informed sampling weights (.e., sampling probabilities proportional assigned weights).

title: Swim Sample — sw_sample
text: length number events wghts Data frame two columns. first column identity grid cell. second column associated sampling weight. choosing option=3, column sampling weights ignored. option Either 1, 2, 3. Default 1. Option 1 uses weighted random assignment distribute events grid cells. option returns grid cell identities. Option 2 distributes events grid cells proportionally according sampling weights. Option 3 distributes events evenly available grid cells, ignoring sampling weights.
